qas.question: ATC responsibilities are usually divided into how many main areas?

plausible_answers.text: non-towered, with no air traffic control presence

qas.question: What describes most clearance delivery systems?

plausible_answers.text: controllers (usually ground-based) direct aircraft movements via radio or other communications links

qas.question: What does a clearance delivery system do at an airport?

plausible_answers.text: safety and speed in complex operations

qas.question: What does apron control offer in busy airports?

plausible_answers.text: into at least two main areas: ground and tower

qas.question: How are clearance delivery responsibilities divided?

plausible_answers.text: via radio or other communications links

qas.question: How does apron control direct aircraft?

context: The majority of the world's airports are <b2_0>non-towered, with no air traffic control presence<b2_0/>. However, at particularly busy airports, or airports with other special requirements, there is an <a0_0>air traffic control<a0_0/> (ATC) system whereby <b3_0>controllers (usually ground-based) direct aircraft movements <b6_0>via radio or other communications links<b6_0/><b3_0/>. This coordinated oversight facilitates <b4_0>safety and speed in complex operations<b4_0/> where traffic moves in all three dimensions. Air traffic control responsibilities at airports are usually divided <b5_0>into at least <a1_0>two<a1_0/> main areas: ground and tower<b5_0/>, though a single controller may work both stations. The busiest airports also have clearance delivery, apron control, and other specialized ATC stations.
